This Half-Life addition sees you playing as a Black Mesa facility security guard, Barney Calhoun, as you experience his trials and tribulations to escape the perils of "the incident" which occurred in Half-Life.  Blue Shift scraps many superfluous weapons from the first game, settling on a modest but satisfactory arsenal. Its storyline, the events that occur and the spectacular sights, along with some quite satisfying puzzles, will keep you entertained the whole way through; that said, it's not very long, as the duration of the game only spans a somewhat 'measly' 6 chapters, so it barely even has enough time to wear out its welcome. However, several high plot points and subtle (or not) details that serve to further intertwine its story's timeline with that of Gordon Freeman himself make the game wonderfully memorable and worth playing, especially if you've played Half-Life first.  Simplified, short, and pretty dang fun, Half-Life: Blue Shift isn't quite that full of a game in its own right, but it seems "just right", with a reasonable arsenal, and a far more manageable length than the first.  Considering it's more of a sister story to the first game, I might even say it serves this function--and then some.  A short but sweet and enjoyable ride.  A memorable experience, it's worth checking out Half-Life: Blue Shift.

Blue Shift is the second expansion to Half Life. Released in 2001, 3 years after the original game. The development was handled by Gearbox - who one day would create games like Brothers in Arms and Borderlands. Blue Shift, was in fact their second game, so you could say that Gearbox was still in the process of learning.
 
The game consists of 5 lengthy chapters and 3 "5 min" chapters. I finished the game in 5 hours, so as you see, it's a pretty short game.

One thing that i did not like is that the plot did not really collide with the plot of Half Life 1 all that much. There were a few cameos, but overall it felt really separated. Basically, you help a group of scientists fix the teleporter and teleport out of the Black Mesa facility. The only cameo is at the start of the game when you see Gordon riding the train.

Gameplay wise, it's basically the same as the original game, except there are no "Class 4" Type weapons (gravity guns and such). The game also has a few puzzles here and there.

In the end though, i like the first expansion (Opposing Force) much more. It had it's own identity i would say.

Oh well. After Playing through Blue Shift on Hard difficulty I have to say that I can understand the criticism this game got. But after all it was a really good ... little campaign. I think the points of criticism (no new Weapons, no Endboss, no new Enemies etc.) are valid considering the original Half Life and its quality. But surprisingly enough these points seemed very fitting to me. I mean after all we aren't the Hero of the story. We are nothing special at all. We are just a security officer that tries to get the hell out of the catastrophy he got into. Why should he use some super powered Weapons ? He uses what he can find. Why should he beat a giant Alien or Endboss ? He is simply trying to get away, not trying to save the world (like Rosenberg pointed out during the Elevator Scene). Other than that I have to say that I found the atmosphere to be really amazing. I felt like a confused lonely surviver trying to stay alive running for his life. All these dark coridors and the environment crumbling away. Electricity shooting out of walls and stuff like that. The biggest personal point of criticism for me is that it only took me 4 hours to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty. Ultimately, if you enjoy the Half Life Universe I can recommend you to play it. Its short, its atmospheric, its intense.

Allright, time for a re-review.
Blue Shift is the last of the side stories for the original Half-Life and once again it was made by Gearbox with help from Valve. But unlike Opposing Force, Valve decided on the story so we won't get any BS Race-X aliens. Anyway, this Side Story lets you play as Barney Calhoun. (The REAL one.)

However, Unlike Gordon and Commander Shepard, G-Man doesn't do a damn thing and You're on your own for this one. So yes, this is the ONLY time in the Half Life series (As of this review) where you work for a happy ending and you GET a happy ending. (Until HL2, that is.)

The weapons that you can use are way and i mean WAY fewer than HL or HL:OF BUT, with the console you can access HL's Weapon list.

If you wanted to know Blue Shift's Weapons: (Crowbar, 9MM, Revolver, Shotgun, Rawket Lawnchair, Satchel Charge, Hand Grenade and the Snarks.) 

Not as much as Opposing Force, but let's be honest: We are only going to use the shotgun, aren't we?

In all, if you wanted to have a quick stroll and look back through time to Black Mesa without the Slog-Fest of Opposing Force or don't want to go through the un-holy mess that is HL's Xen, I would go for this game.

For PC and Sega Dreamcast, It's Half Life: Blue Shift released in June 12, 2001!

PS: this game does NOT have the "ACTION PACKED AMURRIKIA SAVES THE DAY BY KILLIN ALURRENS" or the "WHAT HAS SCIENCE DONE?!?!?!?!?" style that the other two games have. You have been warned.

I must say that I really enjoyed it. In a sense it's basically just more of the first Half-Life. Which is not a bad thing because that means all things that made half-life what it is, including the crouch jumping, crawling in vents and odd puzzles. Even after all this years it really holds well, and it's still a great entertainment. 

Although I kinda wish they would intertwine the story with original one to more degree and used opportunity to reveal more details from different perspective. Freeman is shown couple times, but wouldn't it be cool if you could sometimes see him running around, maybe accidentally helping you unlock a door or turn a power on (or off and make matters more difficult, that selfish bastard :). 

Also It's kinda strange that as an ordinary (but brave) guard you're basically doing the same things as Gordon, only you're expected to do it without H.E.V. suit. Another great thing to see would be a little more humane and humorous side to the Calhoun having the worst job day ever. 

But I guess it's easy now to throw all this ideas writing it on 2013, gaming was different back then (but still has it's charm). To sum up great addition to Half Life series, but not required to play as it doesn't add much to the story.
